title: The Perfect Thread
body:
**The Perfect Thread**

***
“Ok” She takes a deep breath.

“This time. I can do it this time”. 

She restarts the procedure. She’s made herself do this a countless amount of times, all ending the same way; failure. 
She lifts her right leg up, balancing on her left. She steadily takes another breath. Now, the tricky part. 
She closes her eyes and stresses her calm face. 

“I can do this!” She whispers to herself. 

One large shard begins to race around her begin to float, she slightly opens an eye. 

“Errrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr another failure!” She complains. 

She goes out of sync, throwing the rock she ripped from the ground off the mountain ledge. 
The mountain walls around her still remained untouched by her magic, the ground was shredded of stone. 
She takes another deep breath. 

“Come on Taliyah, this is no reason to whine.” She lectures herself. 
“What would Master Yasuo say?” 
She stares off the ledge into Shurima’s corrupt kingdom from the Great Barrier. 

“What would he say…?” Taliyah ponders. 
She pulls out her small, crimson journal from her time with him, flicking through the parched pages… 
**~~-----------------------~~**
She remembers her months with the drunkly wise samurai in Ionia. Her struggles to even control a pebble with her will. 
Yasuo told her he’d seen her control the problematic rock in her sleep while he was on lookout, 
he’d said the mountains would shift whenever Taliyah would try relax on the unmovable earth. 
She remembers the meditating the two did together, 
by the end she would be on a rough raised platform that she had no clue she’d made. 
She'd learnt to force the ground upwards with his guidance. 
She can clearly recall the tunes he'd play with his wooden flute. 
Most of these memoirs were now blurs to her, however there was one event she would not forget. 
It was the two’s third hike to the top of Ionia’s second tallest mountain, 
Taliyah embraced the plateau on the top, Yasuo stared into the sunset taking in the view. 
When Taliyah had noticed his stance, she joined him. They together could see the rim of the mainland. 
Yasuo took a deep breath.

“What have you learnt from this kid?” Yasuo questioned.

“Um… since we’re up here faster than the previous times, that practice is perfect?” She confidently stated. 

“Practice is perfect?” He laughed, “Nothing is flawless, there is no perfection. 
There is practice though. If you practice enough, people will not notice the flaws you make.” 
He assured Taliyah, looking at her questionable expression.

“So you’re not perfect at breaking wind? Always thought you were.” Taliyah cheekily replied.

He sighed, “Exactly kid. But-” He grabbed Taliyah shaking her back-and-forth for attention, 
now both facing each other with the sunset in the background. 

“Look Taliyah, if you remember one thing from all this, remember that perfection does not exist.”

“But-”

“There is no exception. We all have made mistakes before…” He trailed off.

Taliyah had never seen him so serious before; the dead-center concentration of his eyes into hers, 
the tense aura, his eyes wide open, not even blinking, him so out of character and the assurance of her being serious.

“We’re leaving now. Come on.” Yasuo claimed, returning to his usual self and lunging off the ledge. 
Taliyah surprised of his choice, followed her master’s path weaving the mountain under her feet as she went.
**~~-----------------------~~**
…the journal did not need to remind her of his lesson. 
The one bookmarked page of her log from Ionia, ‘**PERFECTION DOES NOT EXIST**’ she’d written in bold. 
“But practice is perfect” She found herself mumbling again, tucking her journal away. 
“You’re wrong master Yasuo!” She shouts in agony down the mountain. 
She took a deep breath. 
“Let’s try again” Taliyah said to herself again. 
She closed her eyes, attempting to tear stone from the walls around her with her magic again. 
Again, the ground rattles uplifting the endless slabs of rock that seem to exist. 
She knows she has failed again, sighing in acknowledgement. 
“Why can’t I weave the walls!” She squeals, kicking the stone she raised. 
She begins to hear someone snicker at her. 
Taliyah goes on guard, looking side-to-side and down the mountain still on her pillar created from the previous failures.

“You never learnt, did you?” She hears from above. 
She looks up, sighting the chuckling Yasuo on top of the untouched cliff side.

“Look kid, tell me ‘Practise is perfect’ when you think you’ve ‘perfected’ your weaving” 
teased Yasuo, jumping down onto the rim of her disaster zone.

“Master Y-Y-Yasuo!” Taliyah barely managed to say, only just being able to stand.

He continued to laugh.

“Kid, most people are afraid of me because they believe I’ve ‘perfected’ the arts. 
I can tell you this, I am not ‘perfect’ at anything. No-one is.” he gazed down onto Shurima.

“M-master! That’s not tru-”

“That is the truth!” he stung. 

“That is all you needed to learn. I have not become ‘perfect’ in the arts. 
I have only mastered them in some areas. Why don’t you do the same?” 
He rhetorically asks, pointing towards the jagged torn earth surrounding Taliyah. He takes a deep breath, 
“This is a nice view point. Did you have to ruin the ground here?”

He once again jumps down the mountainside, creating a trail of debris is his path. 
Taliyah stares down at his decent from her post. Why hadn’t she thought of ‘perfecting’ what she could do? 
She once again, she begins the process, uplifting the ground. 
“Another?” she asks. 
As another rock jerks upwards. 
“And another!” She cheers as another one begins to ascend. 
She laughs in enjoyment of her success, causing the soaring stones to fall back down. 
If she can ‘perfect’ this and use this effectively, she can prove to her master that ‘perfection’ does exist. 
She persists in her tedious trial, shouting “Another” before the fourth pebble rose.

“I’ll prove that ‘perfection’ does exist!” 
She cheerfully shouts down the mountain one final time, with the four stones surprisingly continuing to circle her.

The master barely heard her, but he knew she would say that anyway. 
A grin came to his face, as he was dashing down the mountain. 
“Then show me” he jokingly mumbled.
***

_So. This is my first time doing anything like this at all!
If you're wondering about the inspiration behind this story, I wanted to write something about Taliyah since I really enjoy playing her and learnt about the original idea behind her 'Q', Threaded Volley; basically, the original idea for her 'Q' was going to tear chunks off the walls, so while that was being coded they added her current 'Q' without the worked terrain. The play-testers enjoyed playing with this version of the 'Q' so they chose to stick with it.
This story revolves around why she has her current 'Q' and not the original idea.
Hope you liked the story! I would love to receive feedback on what I've done.
Chow for now.
-Packet_

***

replies.body: Glad you explained the inspiration. Really adds a little bit more to the story :) Though of course, even without it the story was a great read. Thoroughly enjoyed the Yasuo x Taliyah pairing. Very interesting interactions!
